text: On tap at Brewskival. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma and taste has dried fruit, bread, biscuit, slight honey, boubon, vanilla, grain, raisins, wood with a slight alcoholic dried fruity finish

Deep cola brown hue with a fat dissipating head, with a lovely aroma of brown sugar, bourbonny oak, caramel, a touch of coconut and deep dark sugary malty booze. Big boozy and deep flavor thats caramalty, loaded with bourbon and brown sugary coconut and dark malt, oak, and boozy brown sugar again. Just big and sweet and oaked and caramelly.
Sample @ Brewskival, Helsingborg 20160827. Roasted malty, caramely, bourbon, vanilla, sweet, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is sweet and alcoholic with bourbon.

Poured from bottle thanks Dchmela shared with Willrunforbeer for the birth of his son Jacob. Clear burgundy pour with a nice tan head with nice lacing. Aromas of caramel dark fruit raisin toffee bourbon and vanilla. Taste is toffee vanilla nice amount of booze in the finish very smooth balanced oak. Well crafted beer. Congrats Willrunforbeer!

750ml bottle shared by Chalumeaux to help celebrate the birth of my son. Big thanks, TJ! Pours deep dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, dark fruits, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Flavor is toffee, brown bread, bourbon, vanilla, oak. Nice and smooth.
Sample @ Brewskival 27/8-16. Dried fruity with raisins, wood, bourbon and vanilla. Dried fruity finish with raisins, wood, bourbon and vanillla.
Tap @ brewskival Helsingborg Sweden. Pours a dark colour beer with a flat head. Vanilla, oak and Bourbon with licorice and some dried fruit. Dry finish.

Bottle shared.
Thin ring tan head. Clear deep burgundy pour. Plenty of bourbon. Nicely done

Sample, brown bottle, Christmas gathering at Stephen Morriss, savoured on December 18 2015; eye: black, opaque, ring of beige head, slight lacing; nose: roasted barley, bourbon, scotch, caramel, alcohol, bourbon; mouth: roasted barley, bourbon, scotch, caramel, alcohol, bourbon, alcohol warmth, bourbon, finale in alcohol with presence of bourbon, full body, average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly syrupy texture; overall: quite likable
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, bouteille brune, party de Noël chez Stephen Morris, savourée le 18 décembre 2015; il : noire, opaque, anneau de mousse beige, très légère dentelle; nez : orge torréfiée, bourbon, scotch, caramel, alcool, bourbon; bouche : orge torréfiée, bourbon, scotch, caramel, alcool, bourbon, chaleur dalcool, bourbon, finale en alcool avec présence de bourbon, corsée, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amère, texture légèrement sirupeuse; en résumé : bien aimé
sampled at the 2016 brewers ball in tampa. not sure why more companies dont put scotch ales in barrels-I think it works better than stouts and porters.

Bottle shared by tbub18 in Brooklyn (June 2015). I often find Scotch Ales to be too one-dimensionally malty for my tastes, but the barrel aging did wonders here. Its sweet and malty, but its also got waves of bourbon and oak flavor that mingle in to every part of this beer. Delicious.
Bottle shared, thanks! Near black with barely any head. Aroma of big bourbon, vanilla, woody barrel notes, toffee, sweet malt and caramel. Flavour is heavy sweet. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle from Ian at the 2015 Ottawa end-of-year gathering. Very dark mahogany with a very feint beige film. Aroma was overwhelmingly sweet with lots of vanilla, scotch, bourbon, plum, caramel, toffee and raisins. Moderate+ body and mild carbonation, very sweet and almost cloying, very boozy, made me feel slightly diabetic.

Bottle shared by Countbeer. Dark brown to black color, medium sized beige head that diminishes fairly quickly. Aroma is malts, caramel and huge bourbon. Taste malts, sweet, again loads of bourbon, light vanilla, light toffee, caramel, wet raisins. Bourbon flavoured aftertaste with a firm bitterness to it as well. Full body, oily texture, medium but also a bit soft carbonation somehow. Very nice!

Bottle: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Small creamy head/lacing. Dark brown beer.
Aromas of mainly bourbon, butter and caramel with some hints of dried leaves, some spice, marzipan and vanilla and sweet fruit. Very nice!
Flavour is bourbon, vanilla, older wood, dried leaves, some toffee and light caramel, bitters, some prunes, marzipan, hint of bay leaf...
Aftertaste is bitter, toasty, dried leaves, bourbon, wood, etc.
Low carbo, creamy close to silky oily mouthfeel, more than just medium bodied.
Very nice!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: A dark brown ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity caramel malt with Bourbon barrel, licorice, dark fruits, very nice. In mouth, a nice sweet caramel malt with, roasted coffee, bourbon barrel, licorice notes, very nice. Bottle at Ottawa Xmas gathering 2015.

bottle shared by a friend. poured a murky brown colour with a nice thick off tanned head on top. lots of sweet bourbon hits the nose, raisins, sweet toffee, marzipan, vanilla, oak, sweet toffee, lots of balanced flavors. big chewy mouthfeel. a slight notice of charred smoke oak, campfire marshmallows. with a strong sweet bourbon aftertaste. very nice!

Bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour cloudy dark copper with moderate tan head. Nose sweet caramel, toffee, raisin, plum, and hint of barrel. Taste sweet malt up front quickly transition to spicy, slight booze, and plum, raisin. Finish with again slightly boozy and spicy. Thick mouth feel.

Bottle. Pours clear chestnut, small tan head, dissipates fairly quickly, good lacing. Aroma is bourbon, marshmallow, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar. Flavor is fully sweet, dark fruits, raisins, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, a hint of cherries. Medium body, soft mouthfeel. Well done, CCB.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is caramel, bourbon barrel, booze. Appearance is dark ruby, light tan head. Taste is great, lots of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, bourbon barrel, nice. Mouthfeel is perfect, perfect carbonation and thick. Overall, very very nicely done.
Poured from a 750ml bottle. Big bourbon aroma, coconut, vanilla, malty, caramel, raisin. This is big and chewy. Nice.
Sweet, medium bodied, with some nice dark fruit, cloves, vanilla, and light banana caramel flavors. Rich with bourbon and oak notes.

Draft sample Hunahpu Day 2015. Toasted malts, peaty scotch flavors, some smoke, vanilla, oak. Excellent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

At the RBWG-2015. 
Cloudy brown south a limited head.
Plenty of bbl effect. Perhaps a tad too sweet.
Thick full Syrupy body with medium light carbonation.
Lots of whisky [Heaven Hill? ).

Draft at Cigar City Brewing during the RBWG 2015 welcome event. Dark brownish black with light tan ehad. Aromas of dark fruit, chocolate, bourbon, booze. Tastes of bourbon, alcohol, dark chocolate, cocoa, dark fruit, caramel. Full body with a dry finish.

Notes from 4/26/2014. Typical bourbon barrel (brown sugar, vanilla, oak) with some smoked malts, caramel, and toast. I also got some leather (? Cant read my writing). Anyway, I ticked it 4 stars on the day, my notes add up to 4.1. So not too far off.
Draft - Boozy bourbon notes, not much else. Deep brown with a decent beige head. Chocolate, vanilla and light bourbon notes. Balanced roast flavors with a touch of smoke.

Bottled 07.24.14
A: murky brown, lively, nitro looking espresso creamy head. 
S: big tar, chewy baked brownie, bourbon mixed with root beer.
TM: creamy cola feel, rich bourbon is mild. A light booze/burn/warmth on lingers. A bit of sherry sweetness on the back. Sharp tannin like a black pepper burn. 
O: Clean, pronounced flavors, would not expect much more from a BBA Scotch Ale.

Rating #3100. Bottle shared by Tony. Pours brown color with tan head. Aromas of toasted malts, caramel, bourbon, and some oak. Bourbon and toasted malt flavor with caramel, oak, and some nuttiness. Medium body with moderate carbonation.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?x-yt-cl

From notes. This was shared at a tasting put on by @mikem409 on November 7. Poured from a 750 mL bottle. The pour is a dark dark brown, with a little ruby or garnet poking through ad a nice darker head. The aroma is great. There is a lot of big caramel malts and a great vanilla and oak character from the barrel. There is a good lick of bourbon on the back end, which I wasnt expecting entirely. The flavor is really good. There is a lot of caramel and dark fruits to go along with a solid vanilla character and an excellent woodiness. The mouth feel is decently thick and the carbonation had dissipated a bit. There is a boozy heat that really comes through on the back end. The aftertaste is solid. Caramel and dried fruit with just a touch of chocolate and the booze. Really good.
Smell is malt and bourbon. Taste is malt, a slight amount of booze, and a slight amount of chocolate.

Pours a dark brown color with lightly tan colored head. Bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak, and some dark fruits on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with sweetness, and a bourbon warmth. Very complex.

Heavy caramels, fruitiness, bourbon. Drank a batch one the other day and it was still drinking pretty damn well for a beer of this type with this age. Carbonation was low and a touch of oxidation but this is definitely an A-grade BA scotch ale.

November 15, 2014. On tap at All in Beer Fest. Dark brown with a minimal brown head. Aroma is caramel, bourbon, vanilla, oak, light peat and earthy. Taste is sweet caramel, dried fruits, vanilla, light alcohol. Finish is sweet, light peat notes and warming alcohol. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation.
On tap @ AIBF 2014. Dark brown with a small brown head. Fruity and vanilla tones. Vanilla, fruit, wood and malt. Full body with a long bitter / sweet finish.

Draught at AIBF session 3 cons 2014-11-15 Göteborg
AR: bourbon vanilla, chocolate, coffey
AP: dark brown body, wee staouthy head
F: peppery, heavy chocolate, dry, bready, bourbon vanilla, to heavy and to much for me

Draught at All In Beerfest, 2014. Pours murky brown with a small beige head. Aroma is bourbon, corn, raisins, figs, vanilla, some coffee. Taste is bourbon with big malty flavours, toffee, coffee, figs, vanilla, slight warming alcohol in the end. Medium to full body, light to medium carbo, oily texture. Very well balanced, drinkable despite its complex character. Bravo.
Dark brown pour with thin head. Aroma and taste of bourbon, vanilla, light smoke and leather. Hides alcohol really well. Quite complex and very tasty.

Draught at All In Beer Fest 2014, Göteborg. Opaque black beer with a nice beige head. Malty woody aroma, nuts, vanilla, caramel, raisins, figs, toffee, bourbon, some cream. Vinous flavor, raisins, figs, caramel, bourbon, grapes, warming alcohol, spicy notes, some woody notes. Extremely drinkable.
Draught at All In Beer Fest 2014. Murky brown, small head. Fruity, nutty, toffeish, clear vanilla oak notes. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Semi sweet, low bitterness, some tannins.

Probably my second best beer this weekend. Love it.-- bb

Bottle. Actually two. One old rotter, one fresh. Nose on the older is preferred. More vinous character. Taste in the newer has a bit more hop bitterness balance and even a bit of roast. Overall the most recent release is preferred. Solid.

Bottle at the barrel cellar with friends, courtesy of Dave. Thanks man! Pour is deep brown with a big brown head and great lacing. Big bourbon, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, some coconut, coffee and cocoa notes in the aroma. Taste is rich and sweet - brown sugar, some toffee, caramel, coconut, woody, and raisins with a touch of heat on the backend. Thick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Easy drinking for such a big beer.

Bottle share thanks to Beechner224. Oaky, vanilla, malty, peaty, light roast, caramel, light dark fruit. Dark translucent brownish black, brown head. Malty, semi sweet, peaty, and roasty, lots of bourbon and vanilla, hot in the finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown, almost black. Tan head. Aroma is boyrbon and chocolate, much different than the base beer, which we just had. Taste is malty, sweet, slight bourbon sweetness. Pretty tasty beer. Definitely an prove ment over the base.
I loved the non bourbon barrel and I loved this one as much. The barrel added an additional dimension to the already wonderful silky caramel rich brew.

Dark pour, thin brown head. Nose is chocolate and bourbon. Taste is smooth bourbon, chocolate, toffee, caramel, a touch of tart barrel on the finish, dlight dry construction paper. Creamy medium mouthfeel.

Tasted on 2/8/14 from a 750mL bottle at the RBWG Grand Tasting. Pours nearly opaque dark brown with an average tan head that slowly recedes to average, uneven lace. The nose is very sweet caramel, vanilla, maple, and toffee. The flavor has a bit more balanced dryness from some toasted bitterness, but dominated by vanilla, maple, caramel, and toffee. The body is full with just below average carbonation and a long vanilla and somewhat bitter toffee.

Clugs out into the snifter a nearly black with an espresso foam colored head. Caramel and vanilla waft from the glass. Coconut in there too. Rather thick mouthfeel with some burn in the back of the tongue. Sweet up front with the caramel and vanilla. Tobacco leaf appears midway and persists to the finish. Very Parabola-ish. And nearly as tasty!

Bottle poured into. Glass. Get a bourbon smell. Havent really been a fan of big sound. Taste is just as youd expect. The barrel doesnt so much to it. Not worth the money I spent on it.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Almost black pour. Small tan head. Plenty of lacing. Huge malty bourbony aroma. Taste is the same. Awesome malt and bourbon.

Bottle locally from Total Wine in Boca Raton. Had shared at a bottle share. Small snifters. Pours a deep brown with a thick light tan head. Some lacing. Powerful barrel aroma of whiskey/bourbon, dark fruits, booze, oak chips, slight caramel, and vanilla. The taste is close to the aroma with the booze, barrel and dark fruits most dominant and the vanilla creaminess on the back end. Very smooth texture. Slight boozy finish. Damn good beer.

Bottle from Total Wine right near the brewery in Tampa. Pours dark brown color with a big khaki head on top. Big whiskey aromas, vanilla, caramel, molasses, oak. The bourbon is strong with this one. Big rich vanilla, caramel, dark fruit, molasses, bourbon is so smooth here. Big and rich mouthfeel as usual from these guys, low plus carbonation, oh yeah. Another beautiful barrel aged beer from CCB. Yum.
Pours like brown mud into the glass with a whisp of tan head. Aroma is boozy bourbon, figs, and brown sugar. Taste is brown sugar sweetness, spices, toffee, and barrel. Yum

Bottle received in trade. Thank you rfraga7! Pours tiny hazy dark reddish brown with a small frothy mocha head that leaves some lacing and trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet, malty and slightly fruity with caramel, biscuits, toffee, vanilla fudge, coconut shavings, peat, charred wood, raisins, prunes, hay, liquorice fudge and bourbon. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter, malty, and slightly fruity with caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, milk chocolate, coconut milk, charred wood, raisins in rum, figs in brandy, smoked meat, bourbon, liquorice fudge, hay and hints of orange zest. Mouthfeel is soft, round, fat, creamy, boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet, slightly bitter and malty with caramel, biscuits, toffee, vanilla fudge, charred wood, toasted coconut, bourbon, raisins, hay, cocoa powder and hints of liquorice. Sweet, heavy barrel character yet manages to find a vulgar balance.

Bottle tnx to.Alex. Pours dark brown with hints of mahogany red and a good tanned head. Aroma is sweet vanilla a bit acidy very fruity good barrel character malty. Flavor is very good, sweet vanilla and a bit sourish fruity in front plenty of bready and nutty character with more malts in middle and boozy fruity bittering with vanilla towards the end.

ampled at DLD 2014. Thanks guy! This was the better of the Cigar City brews I had that day. Muddy brown color with no head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, caramel, chocolate and cherry. Chocolatey and toffee/caramel flavor to start with vanilla and oak before a bourbon and chocolate finish. Really good stuff.

2012 bottle thanks to fear025. Pours a deep brown with no head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, some vanilla. Taste has a slight coconut/vanilla taste in the end. Alcohol heat. Medium thick body. Light carb. Alcohol burn.
2012 Bottle shared from artmcd8. Nice very bourbon aroma with light salt date raisin licorice. Light carb med bod. Very plum still hottish taste. Harsher than I would have thought.
Dark maroon off white head. Sweet dark fruit and bourbon cherry aroma. Perfect smooth but not flat palate. Barley wine esque. Thanks thiessensce for this one.
Thanks northopfrye! This is awesome. Pours a cola color with tan head. Aromas of vanilla, caramel. Flavors are nice sweet vanilla, butter, caramel and a boozy finish. excellent.

Last years release I believe, green wax. Murky brown pour, heavy barrel notes. Malty as hell, toffee, caramel notes on the nose. Medium texture. The taste follows suite, a little burn from the alcohol, I am sure this would mellow out over time. Pretty rich, probably not order everybody but I dig it

Bottle. Black pour with brown head. Excellent aroma of bourbon, molasses, and dark fruits. This is great as it warms, opening up and drinking surprisingly smooth for a big beer. Certainly a sipper, but no bitterness comes through at all and the bourbon, vanilla/oak and scotch ale base work nicely together.

Bottle. The pour is a dark brown. The aroma is very sweet, slight toffee. The taste is sweet and slight bourbon. Much better than the plain big sound, much better. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle pours cloudy brown orange with small thin head. Nose is fruity bourbon and raisin, molasses. Taste is fruity fig, bourbon, raisin, plum, some oak. Finish is slightly boozy, winter fruits, caramel. Enjoyed it!

Bachelor party scotch ale tasting. 750 mL bottle courtesy of Chris, served in a stem glass alongside the base. Pours deep chestnut with a small tan head that fades to a thin remnant. The nose has big bourbon and toasted oak, along with loads of molasses, brown sugar, toasted malts, herbs and subtle earthy hops. The flavour is similar to the base but with roasty notes and bourbon. It is moderately sweet with toasted malts, caramel, and molasses, along with raisins and a subtle dose of hops. The finish is long with bourbon barrel, toasty and malty notes, along with subtle hops. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture. Overall, this is an amazing scotch ale with beautiful malts perfectly complemented with elegant bourbon notes. 2013-07-25

Bottle: thanks, Mike! Liquid, mahogany body with decent clarity near the edges, topped with a light-tan head that foams up nicely & takes its time settling to a small collar. Aroma is very bourbon heavy, along with notes of prunes, dates, malty brown sugar, caramel, black licorice, wood, & a finishing note of smoke. Taste is even more bourbon forward than the aroma... Huge bourbon kick up front with a lighter backdrop of plums, sweet dates, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, oak, & the slightest hint of vanilla. Cant believe this is only listed at 8.5% ABV. Huge bourbon presence... Maybe a little too big. Still a tasty brew, but time should treat this well.

22oz bobmer via trade drank during my birthday night. Poured a super dark brown, almost black, with a smaller foamy light beige head. Aroma of peat, earth, bourbon, chocolate, syrup, vanilla extract and dark burnt toast. Flavor is boozy, earth, chocolate, alcohol, dark fruit and sweet dark syrup. Full bodied that is syrupy with average to even light carbonation and a lingering flavor with some nice ABV heat.
Sample at faux-bab. Dark brown pour, darker than most scotch ales. Taste and aroma are chocolate and scotch. I get a lot of burnt smokey peat malts. Comes off more of a scotch whiskey than bourbon.

Bottlle from Poreca. It was a great surprise. I love trades where you have a bottle to be named later.Pours black with little head, that fades. Nose is black malt, brownie batter, chocholate liquer and leather. first sip is similar with a lovely toouch of vavilla, oak and ooze. finish is clean wih chocolate syrup flavors.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2014 2011 bottle from my secret santa. Thanks man! Pours a dark reddish brown with a sparse offwhite head. Aroma is big, boozy, strong molasses and bourbon notes. Some chocolate, some caramel. Flavor is strong, hot with booze still, nice bourbon and wood notes. Slick bodied, low carbonation. Finishes boozy.

750ml bottled shared by dmac! Thanks bro! Pours a dark brown/almost black color with a thin fast fading tan head. Aroma is boozy, caramel malt, bourbon, oak, and fresh vanilla bean. Taste is very bourbon forward, lots of caramel and roasted malt, dark fruits, and oak.

Very delicious scotch ale. Very smooth finish that hides the 9% very well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle with Damico. Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma of candi sugar, peat, and smoke. Sweet sugary peaty taste with a light smoke and toffee taste. Medium mouthfeel. Excellent brew!

Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours black with tan head. Aroma of dark candy, peat, smoke and dark roasted grain. Flavor is fairly intense but balanced, malty, peat, light smoke, dark fruit, coffee, toffee, alcohol spice. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, solid brew!!
Deep brown almost black with a khaki head. Bourbon, vanilla, light smoke, alcohol, and leather. Chewy palate, vanilla, peat, smoke, sticky, alcohol, great finish.

Pours dark brown from a 500 cc bottle. Tan head that is quickly fading. Aroma is sweet malt tinged with bourbon and oak with notes of dried fruit and spice. Flavour is wonderful dark sweet malts balanced with oak and bourbon. The bourbon barrel finish adds so much complexity to an already awesome Scotch Ale.

Bottle (2009 vintage drank in 2013): Poured a cloudy dark burgundy color ale with a small dark brown foamy head with light retention and some light lacing. Aroma of bourbon notes with light vanilla with a heavy malt base with quite a bit of residual sugars. Taste is also dominated by heavy caramel malt with quite bit of residual sugar with some medium bourbon notes with light vanilla notes. Body is full with medium carbonation and light warming alcohol notes. Drank very well for a four year old beer but ultimately this beer is a sipper and cant be enjoyed in large quantities.

Green waxed bottle.
Appearance: Deep chestnut with light only visible through edges with a thin light tan head, bubbles are on the edges.
Aroma: Huge vanilla sweetness with strong caramel notes with a mild bourbon backing, hints of oak and fruity undertones.
Taste: Strong syrupy fruit notes on the intro quickly taken over by a strong vanilla with bourbon and oak, while the fruity undertones and sweet caramel underlie it. The finish is of light bourbon with a mild warming sensation and hints of cocoa that linger. Very well balanced, the flavors meld from one to the next very softly.
Palate: Syrupy with light carbonation.
Overall: Wow, this is the best scotch ale Ive had. Beautifully balanced and very drinkable. Well done.

2009 Vintage. Bottle 84/246. 750mL bottle, sent from St. Fun (thanks a lot, Josh), pours an opaque murky dark mahogany with a tiny beige head. Aroma is still quite hot after all these years, with heavy bourbon notes, caramel, and booze. Flavour is extremely potent and rich, full of bourbon barrels, alcohol and rich caramel. Quite boozy, as usual for a Cigar City barrel aged brew. Very round and flavourful, though not as easy drinking as the regular Big Sound. Drinkable in small amounts, but too boozy for much more than that. Decent, but flawed.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2013 A: you can smell the booze from the beer, nice chocolate hint. A: pours dark red with a tan head. The cup lace is very strong. T: has some alcohol at the finish, hop, cocoa and malt. P: full mouthful, very drinkable and some thing I would share with friends.
750 ml. shared bottle. Pours dark brown with an average tan head. Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel, and bourbon. Taste is roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, bourbon, and wood. Very, very good.

Bottle courtesy of randomgarbages rotbox @ randomgarbages wedding reception @ Iowa CIty. Pours a dark brown appearance with a brown head. Sweet smooth bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, a bit woody, soft aroma. Fairly smooth, caramel, a bit oaky, smooth bourbon flavor. Drinks pretty good.
On tap at randomgarbages wedding. Thanks garbage man. Pours a deep brown color with white head. Bourbon, toffee, caramel, oak flavors.

Pours opaque brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma has light roasty malts and mild dark fruit and bourbon.  Flavor has roasty dark fruits, bourbon, light peat, vanilla, and oak.  Mouthfeel is medium and very silky and the finish has light roast, oak, and mild bourbon.
Bottle share at KBBS day, had some nice barrel and chocolate aromas with a tartness. Taste was similar, definitely had an infection issue.

Bottled November 12, 2012. 750 ml bottle into a tulip glass. Huge thanks to dachsundude86 for the bottle. Review #500.

A - Pours a dark, dark red body which lets little light through. One fingers worth of khaki foam with really solid lacing and retention and a touch of alcohol legs.

S - Absurd amounts of raisins and dates, sweet caramel, rich toffee and light peat smoke. This is all followed by a strong bourbon presence of vanilla, oak, and butterscotch. Slight alcohol finish. This is incredible, like a rum raisin ice cream.

T - Very sweet raisins, caramel malts and burnt brown sugar. Well integrated butterscotch, vanilla, and oak from the barrel. This is almost overtly sweet though. Comes back to reality on the finish with light peat and some bitterness. For an 8.5%er this seems awfully large and complex. Mouth feel is thick and creamy, just about spot-on.

O - There is a lot happening in this beer. The aroma is pretty incredible but the flavor, despite its huge sweetness is a bit lacking. Perhaps that is due to the 6 month age it has on it. I havent found a barrel aged CCB that hasnt impressed me yet though.

Mild aroma with a dark brown pour, growing bourbon taste and warming mouthfeel.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Share by bobochamps , drank with the crew of 
Against the grain 
Struise
Alvinne 
And travlr 

Pours black/ brown , no foam .  Sweet , bourbonish .. Borning

Bottle. Very dark mahogany with little else.  aroma is a very sweet rich blend is excellent bourbon and malt roast with light roast nuts.  The flavor is some umami, slightly more sweet and less bourbon with strong wood notes continued on the palate .  Not so big but silky.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2013 75cl, bottled on Nov 12th 2012, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Scotch, woody/sweet and slightly alcoholic/fruity, not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew, yet very expensive!
Poured from a 750 ml bottle. Pours a darker brown with not much head. Aroma has some rum and figs coming through with some raisins. Big booze in the taste.

Green wax bottle traded a few months ago. Pour has a nutty brown color and a coating of tan head that retained a good ring for a barreled beer. Aroma has rich bourbon, oak, vanilla, earthy malts, brown sugar, and a touch of sweetness. Mouth feel is medium heavy and there is average carbonation. Flavor shows that there is plenty of big malts, roast, sweet bourbon, oak, dark fruit, raisins, plenty of sweetness, and a lingering finish.

Bottle from box
aroma, sweet vanilla esters, bourbon esters, old cellar maltness
color, dark brown alittle cloudy,hardly any head, slight tan foam lacing
taste wow mellow bourbon and toffee on the front, vanilla cereral malt mellowness, mixed with deep roasted malts sutle backend mellows to warming feeling, like being in scotland on a Flog course!
overall, wish I had acess to around here, would 100 percent try again, and again, and again.
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Something about this one didnt agree with me. MAripan and maraschino cherries dominate the smell. Flavor is sweet, boozy, but ultimately limp.

dark brown and amber. no head
lots of bourbon, raisins and figs. yeah lots of raisins
Great classic scotch ale taste, very very sweet, lots of dark fruits like raisins. A hint of vanilla and hazelnut. Tons of sweet brown sugar.

Bottle. Mahogony beer with a dark tan head. Bourbon and vanilla aroma with rich malt. Rich malt/caramel flavor with bourbon, light fruitiness, and light chocolate. Medium-plus bodied. Rich malt/caramel linger with fruitiness, bourbon, and vanilla.

Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.  From notes.

Bourbon Barrel Big Sound has a full, opaque brown color in the glass.  There was a tiny head on top after the initial pour, but it faded to nothing rather quickly.  

The nose is a sign of good things to come.  Bourbon, oak, and vanilla gracefully step in brown of caramel, burnt sugar, orchard fruits, and peat.  

Typical Scotch Ale sweetness starts off the flavor, with brown sugar and toffee leading the way.  Quickly the bourbon barrels send the rest of the sip on a less sweet trajectory, smoothing out the sugars with a nice bourbon and vanilla presence.  There is general fruitiness in the middle of the sip that works nicely with the other flavors as well.  Woody oak notes blend well with the peat notes in the original beer.  The end finishes smooth, with the flavors coming together and wrapping up nicely.

Where I may be most impressed with this beer is in the body.  Not only does the beer survive the barrel aging process with its body intact, it actually drinks bigger than the 8.5% that it is.  It seems that instead of wearing away at the body, the barrel aging process only removed some of the sweetness and added a smoothness to the texture that I like.  If anything, the carbonation seems a little light.

Cigar City has done a very good job with their barrel program.  Nearly every beer they have chosen to age in barrels has emerged better than when it went in.

Deep dirty browns, his khaki foamy head recedes into a khaki collar while the middle is marked by random bubble scatterings. When I tease his murky depths, I find lace kindly left behind. Dipping my nose in for the kill, I am suddenly standing before a never-ending supply of caramel nougat truffles dusted with cinnamon powder while rich vanilla perfumes the air. Graham crackers crunch under my watchful nose and bourbon oozes out of the porous wood barrels in which they used to rest. An interesting addition, maraschino cherries flitter about the wood, bourbon, and caramel nougat truffles before one last kiss of treacle brings me into supping beervana. His body is sublimely smooth and marked by creamy sweetness. Toasted marshmallows find themselves right at home with the graham crackers and vanilla while the back of his swallow pierces with heavy caramel sweetness. As I bite into each quaff, I find his soft caramels and cinnamon dusted truffles filled with the richest of bourbons. Slivers of vanilla extract can be found as I dig through each flavorful quaff. Bourbon warms my breath and the gentle dryness of wood settles atop my tongue for that always classic interplay of palate cleansing and thirst inducing pleasures. A beer to be supped slow and at room temperature, I find that the more he warms the more his flavors melt into each other. Filled with warm fuzzies, I settle in for a slow session of beervana inspired by Cigar City Brewing.

Palate:Full body with mild carbonation.
Overall:Excellent.  Bourbon was well done and added to the overall experience.

Skyview Tasting 2.5.  Courtesy of Skyview.  Dark brown color with no head.  Oaky aroma, lots of vanilla and brown sugar.  Thick and chewy malt up front.  Very light peat, a bit of saltiness, caramel and oak along with its requisite vanilla.  The oak did wonders for this beer.

Acquired a 750 ml bottle via trade with Hopscotch. From bottle 216/246 pours a semi-hazy dark reddish amber colored brew with a thin and fast dissipating off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, some dark pitted fruits, vanilla, a hint of caramel and some floral hops. Taste is full bodied compared to the regular Big Sound Scotch Ale, flavors of bourbon, vanilla, dark pitted fruits and some alcohol. Finish is boozy, slightly metallic with some vanilla and dark fruit aftertaste.

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy red brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, dried fruits, bourbon and vanilla with notes of oak.
Sweet flavour of caramel, dried fruits, vanilla, bourbon and oak with notes of alcohol.
Sweet and alcoholic finish.
The alcohol is too dominating.

Bottle.  Similar to the regular version with a dark brown pour with little carbonation.  However the aroma was much better, plenty of good bourbon which gradually gave way into a much better flavor.  Tons of woody, boozy, silky and somewhat sweet and complex beer.  Awesome!!

Bottled 1/246. A murky amber beer with a thin orangey head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, over ripe fruits, bourbon, and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of caramel, alcohol, and a bit of wood, leading to a dry alcoholic finish where the wood lingers. The alcohol burns in the mouth. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Bottled Ƒ/246). Reddish brown coluored. unclear. Dense brown head. aroma of spice, carmel, sweetness, vanilla and wood. Flaovur is sweet and spiced. Has yeast, light roastt nd fruits. Smooth and balanced. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a spiced fruity note with a light alcohol bite. Very well made.

75 cL bottle, 1/246. Pours cloudy to hazy dark orange with a small tan head. Aroma is solid alcohol and roasted malt aroma. Sweet, caramelish and mild yeasty flavoured. Light phenolic. Mild fruity and roasted malty flavoured into the far finish. Smooth bourbon note into the far finish.

Hazy red brown color; small head. Strong vanilla oak aroma, old wood. Medium body strength, good caramel flavor, with some residual sweetness and light smoke touch; lightly nutty too, mostly in the final; the alcohol gives a warming feeling. Good.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of Retorp. Bottle # 1/246. Hazy orangey golden with a small, off-white head. Distinct aroma of bourbon and ashes. Solid body, sweet caramel, nuts and ashes, vaguely peaty. Hardly any bitterness in the finish, but warming alcohol and Bourbon. Certainly appears stonger than 8.5%. 220909

750mL bottle #244/246 courtesy of a very, very generous Tampa BA, poured into a snifter.

Pours dark brown in the glass with some mahogany hues coming through around the edges.  There is a very small tan head that recedes very quickly, leaving a small collar and a swirl of bubbles along the top.

Much like the regular version, Im not overly impressed with the nose as its fairly faint and mostly sweet caramel malts and brown sugar.  The bourbon is present but definitely not overpowering.

The taste is markedly better than the aroma for me as the malts take on a more smoked peat character in addition to the caramel sweetness.  There are dark fruits, raisins and figs, in the middle before the bourbon makes an appearance in the finish leaving a nice burn going down.

The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with soft carbonation and very smooth.  Though the smoked peat lends a slight dryness to the finish, its still a sweet, sugary feel on the palate.

This is a step up from the regular Big Sound for me as the bourbon brings an extra complexity to the taste without being the dominant component.  Very nice.

[Bottle] shared by Skyview. Pours a cloudy brown with almost no head. Aroma is the usual suspects, vanilla, caramel, alcohol, coconut, oak, and cocoa powder. Flavor is cardboardy oxidation, some smoke, light carbonation, some sweetness.

Thanks to Skyview for sharing.  Sweet bourbon aroma - more of a port character than anything else.  Hazy bron color.  A light bourbon character with some oak funk coming through on the finish.  Mostly fruity malts in the flavor.

9th Richmond RB Gathering, courtesy of dkachur. Bottle 214/216. Dark fruits, raisin roast chocolate vanilla and wood in aroma. Clear very dark amber brown with little head. Flavor has big roastyness and a nice whiskey presence with chocolate and moderate grain astringency. Finish is malty with moderate residual bitterness and nice warming.

Missed the release but thanks to the CCB boys for taking care of me! Bottle 75/246

A: Pours a very dark amber hue, more brown than red. Nice tall creamy tan head that rises to a full finger. Excellent retention with tons of thick sticky lace. CCB beers really are beautiful in the glass.

S: Wonderful aromas. Lots of toffee, brown sugar, loads of caramel malt. Lots of barrel as well. Old oak, vanilla, and hints of booze.

T: Pretty damn drinkable for a BA brew. Lots of malt sweetness. Toffee forward, brown sugar, and sweet molasses. Hints of apple and dark fruit in the middle. The finish is about the barrel. Not over the top at all, just subtle oak, vanilla, and a touch of booze which compliments the base beer nicely.

M: Medium in body, smooth mouthfeel.

D: Pretty good actually. Not the best barrel aged CCB brew, but the barrel did improve an already solid base brew!
9th Richmond Gathering, courtesy of dkachur.  Aroma is of oak, vanilla, faint alcohol.  Flavor is more boozy than the nose, bourbon, oak, more molasses.  Good, but I preferred the regular version.

750 mL bottle... #214/246. Courtesy of tarheels86. Pours a hazy dark brown color with not much of a head. The aroma is sublime. Caramel, toffee, leafy hops, vanilla, maple, bourbon, faint smokiness, booze and green apple. Taste is caramel, toffee, bourbon, wood, faint smoky notes, leafy hops, something faintly cheesy. Full bodied and very smooth. The regular Big Sound is a phenomenal beer but the bourbon works with this too well. This is epic. Fantastic beer.

Bottle shared by emacgee. Thanks Ethan.  Nose of big caramel, light bourbon, big malts, a lot like the original.  Flavor shows some more bourbon than the nose, wood, peat, vanilla, scotch. Very nice and warming.

Thanks to David for sharing this one! I actually enjoyed this slightly more than the regular version of Big Sound, even though I wasnt crazy for it. The almost over-the-top sweetness of regular BS seems fit just a hair more with the smooth bourbon/vanilla profile the barrel lends. Slight smoke and fruits in the general confection, this one was pretty good.
Copper pour with a thick beige head.  Caramel, roast, and bourbon on the nose.  Sweet malts, bourbon, vanilla, and dark fruit

Geez, I barely remember tasting this one.  Good thing I took notes at the tasting.  Brown pour with slight red tint. Nice tan head.  Caramel, some mild peat, bourbon on the nose as well as vanilla.  Sweeter than the regular version, as is the taste.  Good, but I prefer the non barrel-aged version.

Pours out dark brown with some foam. Smells sweet and boozy. Taste is big malty with woody bourbon. Flavors of caramel, toffee, peat, vanilla and oak. Smooth sticky finish with nice alcohol warming. Another very good brew.

Thanks fishingnet for the trade. Pours a murky brown with a one finger tan head. The nose is sweet, shows some caramel malt, mill tannic oak, very mild bourbon, fruity. The flavor is malty, shows some mild peat, tannic oak, warming alcohol, mild vanilla, woody. Palate is tannic and warm.

2009 Bottle sample at Noogfest High 5 thanks to jcwattsrugger.  Poured brown with a tan head that settles to a ring. Nice scotch aroma with a vanilla and toffee. The flavor also found vanilla and scotch with a nut and malt background. Medium body, slight alcohol warming, creamy smooth. Awesome!
Light brown pour with off white creamy head and lace. Aroma of light brown sugar and peatiness. Sweet caramel malt, a hint of abv and a nice earthy peat flavor. Medium bodied with good carbonation.
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2009 Like a watery Belgian strong, flavor of Alcohol is strong. Thanks to either JW77, Daknole, or Ryan.

Kindly shared by the GodOfThunder. Pours a nice thick brown with a creamy tan head. Nose is bourbon, caramel, lush touches of chocolate and vanilla, brown sugar as it warms. The unbarreled version didnt strike me as particularly sweet, but this comes across as pleasantly sweet with caramel, oak, bourbon, vanilla, hints of cherries and dates, some chocolate, lots of malt. Drying sensation from barrel tannins and the alcohol, quite lush, lots of small bubbles, not syrupy. The barrel served this well!

22oz wax sealed bottle (#60). Pours a burnt mahogany, relatively clear. Big foamy off white head. Nose is huge caramel and bourbon notes. A bit of wood and a whiff of smoke. Flavor is very bourbony up front but recedes enough to let the scotch ale breathe. Caramel and chocolate dominate this version where the fruitiness of the normal big sound is more subdued here. Less fruit esters and more complex malt. Finishes with a slight cherry pit and big caramel flavor. Slightly warming with a touch of sweet bourbon. Another terrific barrel aged beer.

Damn.  This is good.  Real good.  Very sweet, though.  Like a dessert, but not overly sweet that you cant easily drink an entire bottle on your own.  The bourbon barrel aging almost adds a more caramel maltiness to the already malty scotch ale.  A lot of toffee, caramel, brown sugar and milk chocolate on top of a malt bomb.  Theres a little oak and the bourbon is sweet and accentuates everything.  This is amazingly good and easy to drink.  This would be on my Top Ten list for beers to drink for the rest of my life.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2009 (Rating #5200) Draft This beer rocks! Murky, dark, burnt caramel-colored ale with a small, fat-bubbled, off-white head. The aroma is a lavish blend of  bourbon, vanilla, singed caramel, smoke, tobacco and burnt marshmallow. Full-bodied with a chewy mouthfeel and modest carbonation. The flavor is a swirl of bourbon, caramel, espresso, chocolate, vanilla and toffee. Finishes sweet, boozy and rich. World class Scotch ale!

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Quaffed (THIS WAS NEVER ON DRAFT) at CCB BA Big Sound release party. Big thanks to Justin for opening his bottle. It pours murky dark brown  amber with copper edges and lasting tan head. The aroma is bourbon  whiskey notes and some heat to go along with modest sweet maltiness. The taste is sweet malty and chewy with a brief pulse malt roastiness before layers and layers of bourbony booze barrel notes well up to the surface. To midway and toward the finish I get thin mesas of chocolate, some dark roasted coffee and mildly drying roasted malts and booze.

Bottle from CCB Big Sound Release Party. Pours a muddy dark brown to black with a massive tan creamy head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and malty with subtle bourbon notes and other notes of vanilla, carmel, toffee, ripe dark fruit, some hints of toffee and wood. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of bourbon, vanilla, wood, caramel, toffee, chocolate, some hints of a light nuttiness. Generally medium body with a pleasing malty, light bourbon finish. Bourbon definitely does not overpower this beer but complements all the great flavors lurking about.

750ml bottle cracked by jdubfl.  Thank bro!  The pour yields a dark and hazy plum-brown colored body with a small layer of whipped, khaki tinted foam.  Little splotches and dots of lacing mark the glass.  The nose kicks off with a big, woody bourbon overtone that really compliments the underlying malt collage, notes of nougat, caramel, cocoa, figs and raisins all lending rich, earthy, fruity depth.  Though it is warm and a little boozy in its youth, the bourbon flavors massage the cocoa and stewed dark fruits well.  The lingering finish offers notes of dark cherry, vanilla, and oak.  Though its been thinned a bit by the barrel, the palate is still quite lush, with a distinct creaminess and a warming, sherry-like finish.  Excellent brew, though I must say I preferred the regular version on cask a bit more.

Thanks to jdubfl for sharing this bad boy at the release party.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Nose is bourbon, vanilla, sugar, toffee, caramel, and a hint of magic.  Flavor is very similar with lots of bourbon and big malt to support the bourbon.  Lingering sweet malt/ bourbon finish to this medium bodied beer.  Enjoyable beer.

My god CCB does it again.  Amazing.  Dark brown pour, tan head.  Aroma is really wonderful.  Tons of bourbon, toffee, vanilla, oak and dark dried fruit.  Flavor is loaded with smooth oak and bourbon notes, some vanilla, caramel, light smoke and holy hell what a mouthfeel.  This one is a big step up from the regular big sound.  WOW.  But what do I konw, I am just a homer.

Bourbon, vanilla, oak, with molasses and rich caramel with hints of chocolate in the aroma.  Pours murky brown with an off white head.  Wow this is like a dessert in a glass, so rich, intense caramel with vanilla, oak, hints of bourbon, chocolatey with hints of dark cherries.  Awesome!

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown color with a thin tan head, lots of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is earthy, lots of bourbon, wood, and malt.  Pretty full bodied almost chewy with soft carbonation.  Tastes a little hot right now, I expect you could lay this one down for a while.  Huge malt presence, the barrel really imparted a lot of bourbon on this one also present are vanilla, wood, chocolate, and rasin.  Finishes slightly sweet with lots of alcohol.  Glad I have a couple to age.

Pours a deep brown with tan head. Nose is bourbon, wood, some smoke, alcohol, roasted grain, raisin, and sweet caramel. Flavor is dark fruits, whiskey, vanilla, wood, some charred grain, plum, raisin and caramel. The bourbon is so very smooth. Makes this beer very very enjoyable.

750 ml brown bottle, sealed with burgundy wax. Bottle # 110 of 246.
Kind of appropriate, huh? Poured out a deep chocolate brown, with a sticky tan head. Aromas are of rum soaked raisins, alcohol, molasses, some bittersweet chocolate. Flavors are of alcoholic rum soaked raisins, bittersweet chocolate, slight yeasty bite, some biscuit malt. 
Oak barrel in the background, definite hint of bourbon in the tastes.
Full, rich mouthfeel, almost chewy. Definitely a top notch brew. Thanks to Wayne & the crew at CCB for sending me this special brew.

Bottle sample at Noogfest High 5.

Poured a hazy dark brown color with a moderate frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Medium toasted malt, wood and earthy scotch aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy bourbon bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration.

A smooth complex drinkable brew.

Sampled at Noog 5.  Cloudy brown pour with a minimal head.  Slightly smokey aroma with peat, and a touch of malt sweetness.  Over all it is a fairly mild smelling brew.  The flavor is full of peat malt.  There is cola with a touch of wood bourbon barrel that imparts a creamy note more than anything.  A touch of vanilla also, like you might find in root beer.  Full creamy mouth feel.

This poured a murky brown color with some molasses, peat, and toffee in the nose. The flavor is rather sweet and malty with some caramel, molasses, nutty flavors, and toffee. Some alcohol in the finish. Overall a nice beer

Noogfest High 5. Sample from a bottle thanks to jcwattsrugger.  Dark brown-red with a thin off white head.  Aroma is bourbon, oak.  Taste is light smoke, caramel, molasses, charred oak, light chocolate.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2015 750ml bottle @Noogfest High5pours a light tan ring for a head and dark amber color.  Aroma is bourbon, dark malt-sweet molasses, peat, secondary hops bite.  Taste is bourbon, dark malt-sweet molasses, peat, secondary hops bite, some earthy/ashy.  
150219 @brewery 750 bottle. clean no earthy musty.

Sampled at Noogfest High 5. The body was dark brown with a khaki head. The aroma was bourbon, vanilla and wood. The taste was sweet bubblegum and some wood. Lots of oak, too much for my taste. There was also some vanilla. Good for the style, but not for me.

Sampled at Noogfest High 5. Pours cloudy reddish brown with slight beige head. The aroma is Scotch, caramel, earth, and toffee. The flavor is tobacco, toffee, barrel char, with a tasty earthy finish. A very enjoyable beer.
